text: the United Nations is facing both a
personal and humanitarian crisis several
of its people apparently have been
killed in the collapse of the UN
headquarters in port-au-prince Haiti
meantime the United Nations is gearing
up to distribute humanitarian aid to the
devastated country for more on that
story we're going to Neil MacFarlane
aight admissions in New York now let's
start with what you know now about the
collapse of the UN headquarters there in
port-au-prince and the number of death
we're hearing that there are several
well details are sketchy because of
course telecommunications have collapsed
they're trying to get through via
satellite they do know that the
christopher hotel which was up in
petionville which is sort of the richer
area in the hills was badly affected
there were 100 to 150 UN staffers in the
hotel at the time the chief of mission
mr. haryana be a tunisian was meeting
with the Chinese delegation he is still
unaccounted for they have pulled five
people out of the rubble so far as of
this morning and they have about 9,000
troops in total in the peacekeeping
force that's in Haiti and 3,000 of them
are in and around port-au-prince now
what kind of activity is going on there
around the UN headquarters here in New
York where you are trying to send in
reinforcements what's the plan so far as
you know it but you know they said it's
a major humanitarian crisis there of
course mobilizing the various agencies
of the UN the humanitarian relief the
World Food Programme they are all sort
of gearing into gearing up to send extra
supplies since it's just happened last
night there isn't really a plan
formulated yet they have pulled 10
million dollars from their emergency
fund so far and they expect for a
worldwide appeal in a few days when they
when they know the extent of the damage
and what what needs to be sent they're
also calling for international search
and rescue teams to be sent and and
medical crews and Neil this is a large
loss of life for the UN actually
in this sort of disaster what kind of
human reaction are you sensing there at
the headquarters you know it's sort of
in crisis mode at the moment so people
are kind of going from meeting to
meeting they don't really know yet it
hasn't really been confirmed how many
people were killed you know if it is
it's probably mostly concentrated in
that headquarters staff they said before
I let you go you were in Haiti back in
the spring Haiti is in dire straits even
in normal times how do you imagine the
people of haiti coping with this kind of
disaster yeah one of the first questions
asked of course at the briefing this
morning was served about the security
situation on the streets because of
course the government was toppled in
April of 2008 due to food riots in Haiti
and also the country has been hit by a
devastating series of hurricanes in 2008
which killed more than 800 people so it
was already sort of on the UN's list of
countries that needed help and
assistance from around the world so it
really is a whammy on top of a situation
that was already difficult and I'm sure
they're just reeling and trying to
figure out how they're going to cope
with that you know I've one last thing I
knew you know you hear that the people
of haiti are we're very resilient and
inventive was that your experience and
is that going to help them know they are
really resilient I mean you know the
minimum wage there is a dollar
seventy-five an hour and people find
ways to exist on that so I'm sure that
they'll cope with this but you know
again it's a city of 2 million people
with a lot of not a lot of resources so
they're going to go through a very
difficult time Neal thank you so much
for your time any time
